required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: AGIR Study: Angio-Seal in Interventional Radiology
clinical_study.official_title: Efficacy Superiority of Angio-Seal™ vs. Manual Compression in Interventional Radiology

brief_summary.textblock:
Clinical study in patients undergoing any intervention requiring vascular access to the femoral artery. The study compares Angio-Seal™ vs. Manual Compression with regard to control the vascular access.
It is designed to demonstrate superiority of the Angio-Seal™ with an unchanged risk-profile.

detailed_description.textblock:
Patients will have their puncture closure randomly performed by one of these approved methods: Angio-Seal™ Closure device or Manual Compression.
Patients will be enrolled in the study during 12 months, with a follow-up period of 2 weeks (± 1 week).
The randomization will be stratified according to the type of procedure.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Patients With Mobilization Time Between 0-4 Hours
primary_outcome.description: Mobilization Time is the time that patient gets the authorization to flex the leg, sit or walk.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Patients With Mobilization Time Between 4-48 Hours
secondary_outcome.description: Mobilization Time is the time that patient gets the authorization to flex the leg, sit or walk.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Patients With Any Complications
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At puncture closure procedure, at discharge and at follow up (2 weeks+/-1 week)
secondary_outcome.description: Number of patients with any complications since the puncture closure until 2 weeks ± 1 week. The complications are related to the puncture closure evaluated at closure, discharge and follow-up. These include hematoma, Inferior limb ischemia, prolonged pain at puncture site, puncture site local infection, pseudoaneurysm, significant bleeding and vessel occlusion.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Patients With Time to Hemostasis Between 0-4 Minutes
secondary_outcome.description: Time to hemostasis is the time from the beginning of closure procedure, until the physician take away their hands from the patient, regardless the closure procedure, and confirm the "stop of bleeding".

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Patients With Time to Hemostasis Between 4-60 Minutes
secondary_outcome.description: Time to hemostasis is the time from the beginning of closure procedure, until the physician take away their hands from the patient, regardless the closure procedure, and confirm the "stop of bleeding".

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to Discharge From Interventional Radiology Department
secondary_outcome.description: Time that the physician grants the patient the discharge order from the Radiology Department. If the patients has order to be hospitalized up to 24h after the puncture closure by the radiologist, then, the discharge from the radiology department will be 24h, even if the patient needs to continue hospitalized in other department.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Patients With Angio-Seal™ Deployment Success
secondary_outcome.description: According the physician criteria, it will be "YES" If the anchor was deliver properly, the absorbable component remain in the correct point of the arterial puncture and no bleeding in the skin puncture.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patient ≥ 18 years Interventional Radiology procedures with Femoral Artery puncture (4 French - 8 French Introducers)
- Patient available for follow-up at 2 weeks
- Patients who are willing to participate and have signed an Ethic Committee approved patient informed consent.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Access unsuitable for use of Angio-Sea
- Presence of calcification at the puncture site
- Presence of visible hematoma at the end of the procedure
- Patients who are unable to comply with the follow-up schedule based on their geographic location or for any reason.
- Patients who are pregnant.
- Patients currently participating in a clinical investigation that includes an active treatment arm.
- Contraindication for ambulation at 2 hours after the end of the procedure
- Patients with a life expectancy of less then 1 month.

overall_official.affiliation: Hospital Universitario de La Princesa, Madrid

event.description: MINOR STROKE LEFT SIDE
DETERIORATION OF THE GENERAL CONDITION OF THIS GERIATRIC PATIENT
FEVER, EDEMATOASCITIS DECOMPENSATIS, INFERIOR EXTREMITIES CELLULITIS GREATER IN COUNTER LATERAL PUNCTION SITE
HEPATIC ABSCESS. DISCHARGE ON 3/06/2011
SERIOUS URINARY TRACT INFECTION IN AN ELDERLY PERSON
BLEEDING OF THE PUNCTURE SITE
PERFORATION SUPERFICIAL FEMORAL ARTERY
SIGNIFICANT BLEEDING AFTER MANUAL COMPRESSION WITH PROLONGATION OF MANUAL COMPRESSION AND PROLONGED HOSPITAL STAY.
HEMATOMA AFTER 24 HOURS AT PUNCTURE SITE
PROLONGED PAIN AT THE PUNCTURE SITE. VESSEL STENOSIS
BIGGER BRUISE : SMALL HEMATOMA LESS THAN 6 CM SIGNALED BY THE PATIENT
FAILURE OF INTRODUCTION OF THE INTRODUCER OF THE ANGIO-SEAL WITH SIGNIFICANT BLEEDING.
BIGGER BRUISE OF THE PUNCTURE AREA AND WENT TO A GENERAL PRACTITIONER
HEMATOMA AFTER 5 DAYS OF INTERVENTIONAL PROCEDURE
BRUISE IN THE PUNCTION AREA STILL PRESENT AT PHONE CALL VISIT
BLEEDING AFTER CLOSURE PROCEDURE
BLEEDING AFTER CLOTURE PROCEDURE
SLIGHT PAIN AT PUNCTURE SITE
HEMATOMA DURING THE PROCEDURE RELATED TO CALCIFICATION
SMALL HAEMATOMA (+/- 1 CM)
PAIN IN THE PUNCTURE AREA
ACUTE HEADACHE + ONE TIME VOMITING AFTER CAROTID STENTING

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: This study has been early terminated on 15 May 2014 due to low enrollment rate and the publication of other larger studies about closure device versus manual compression.This lead to small number of subjects analyzed.
